t: Proverbs 22
On Life and Conduct
A*pn good*i name is to be more desired than great wealth, Favor*ln is better than silver and gold.
The*ln rich and the poor have a common bond, The*ln Lord*s is the maker of them all.
The*ln prudent sees the evil and hides himself, But*ln the naive go on, and are punished for it.
The*ln reward of humility and*i the fear of the Lord*s Are*ln riches, honor and life.
Thorns*ln and*i snares are in the way of the perverse; He*ln who guards himself will be far from them.
Train*ln up a child in the way he should go, Even*ln when he is old he will not depart from it.
The*ln rich rules over the poor, And*ln the borrower becomes*i the lender’s slave.
He*ln who sows iniquity will reap vanity, And*ln the rod of his fury will perish.
He*ln who is generous will be blessed, For*ln he gives some of his food to the poor.
Drive*ln out the scoffer, and contention will go out, Even*ln strife and dishonor will cease.
He*ln who loves purity of heart And*iln whose speech is gracious, the king is his friend.
The*ln eyes of the Lord*s preserve knowledge, But*ln He overthrows the words of the treacherous man.
The*ln sluggard says, “There is a lion outside; I*ln will be killed in the streets!”
The*ln mouth of an adulteress is a deep pit; He*ln who is cursed of the Lord*s will fall into it.
Foolishness*ln is bound up in the heart of a child; The*ln rod of discipline will remove it far from him.
He*ln who oppresses the poor to make more for himself Or*ln who gives to the rich, will*i only come*i to*i poverty.
Incline*ln your ear and hear the words of the wise, And*ln apply your mind to my knowledge;
For*ln it will be pleasant if you keep them within you, That*ln they may be ready on your lips.
So*ln that your trust may be in the Lord,*s I*ln have taught you today, even you.
Have*ln I not written to you excellent things Of*ln counsels and knowledge,
To*ln make you know the certainty of the words of truth That*ln you may correctly answer him who sent you?
Do*ln not rob the poor because he is poor, Or*ln crush the afflicted at the gate;
For*ln the Lord*s will plead their case And*ln take the life of those who rob them.
Do*ln not associate with a man given*i to anger; Or*ln go with a hot-tempered man,
Or*ln you will learn his ways And*ln find a snare for yourself.
Do*ln not be among those who give pledges, Among*ln those who become guarantors for debts.
If*ln you have nothing with which to pay, Why*ln should he take your bed from under you?
Do*ln not move the ancient boundary Which*ln your fathers have set.
Do*ln you see a man skilled in his work? He*ln will stand before kings; He*ln will not stand before obscure men.
